ChatGPT said:

Heres a step-by-step guide on how to test page load speed using Google Lighthouse and GTmetrix:

Using Google Lighthouse (in Chrome DevTools):

  1. Open Chrome DevTools:

    • Open Google Chrome.
    • Load your website.
    • Right-click anywhere on the page and select Inspect to open Chrome DevTools (or press Ctrl+Shift+I on Windows/Linux or Cmd+Opt+I on macOS).

  2. Run Lighthouse:

    • Inside Chrome DevTools, click on the "Lighthouse" tab (you might need to click the >> icon to find it if it's not visible).
    • Select the categories you want to test (by default, "Performance" is selected, which includes page load speed).
    • Choose a device (Desktop or Mobile) to simulate loading times on different devices.
    • Click Generate Report to run the test.

  3. Review Results:

    • Once Lighthouse runs the audit, it will provide a detailed report.
    • Focus on the Performance section. Check the First Contentful Paint (FCP) and Largest Contentful Paint (LCP) metrics, which are key indicators of page load speed.
    • Ensure that the First Contentful Paint (FCP) or Largest Contentful Paint (LCP) is less than 2 seconds for an optimal page load time.

Using GTmetrix:

  1. Visit GTmetrix Website:

    • Go to GTmetrix.
    • Create a free account if you dont have one to unlock more testing options.

  2. Test Your Website:

    • Enter your website's URL into the input box on the homepage.
    • Click Test your site.

  3. Review Results:

    • Once the test completes, GTmetrix will show a detailed report with load times and performance scores.
    • Focus on the Fully Loaded Time metric.
    • Ensure the load time is under 2 seconds.

Interpreting Key Metrics (from Lighthouse or GTmetrix):

  • First Contentful Paint (FCP): This is when the browser renders the first piece of content (text, image, etc.) to the screen.
  • Largest Contentful Paint (LCP): This measures how long it takes for the largest content element to be fully visible.
  • Time to Interactive (TTI): This measures how long it takes for the page to become fully interactive.

Expected Result:

  • Both tools should show that the First Contentful Paint (FCP) or Largest Contentful Paint (LCP) is under 2 seconds.
  • GTmetrix should show a Fully Loaded Time of under 2 seconds as well.

By following these steps, you'll be able to accurately test the page load speed and identify areas of improvement. If the page load time is greater than 2 seconds, you can optimize by:

  • Compressing images.
  • Reducing unnecessary scripts.
  • Enabling caching.
You said:
when im doing refresh to the page it says that page not found , how to fix this ? i deployet it on vercel
ChatGPT said:

The issue of getting a "Page not found" error after refreshing the page is common when deploying Single Page Applications (SPAs) like those built with React on platforms like Vercel. The problem arises because SPAs manage routing on the client side, while a server (like Vercel's) expects to handle routing requests.

Here's how you can fix this:

Fixing "Page Not Found" on Refresh in Vercel:

  1. Create or Update the vercel.json Configuration: To ensure Vercel correctly handles the routing of your SPA, you'll need to create or update a vercel.json file in the root of your project. This file instructs Vercel to serve index.html for all routes, so the SPA's client-side routing takes over.

    • Add the following configuration to your vercel.json:
    json
    {
  "rewrites": [
    {
      "source": "/(.*)",
      "destination": "/index.html"
    }
  ]
}
    • This configuration ensures that for any route, Vercel serves the index.html file so that React's client-side routing can handle the request.

  2. Deploy the Update:

    • Commit your changes, including the vercel.json file.
    • Push the updates to your Git repository, which will automatically trigger a new build and deployment on Vercel.

  3. Check Your Vercel Deployment:

    • Once the build is complete, refresh your page to see if the issue is resolved. Now, even when you refresh the page, the correct component should load because Vercel will serve the SPAs entry point (index.html) for all routes.

Why This Works:

  • Client-Side Routing in React: React Router (or other client-side routers) handles routing in your application. However, when you refresh the page, the server (Vercel) tries to find the route directly, but it doesn't exist server-side.
  • Rewriting All Routes to index.html: By rewriting all routes to serve index.html, Vercel allows the React app to take control and handle routing correctly.

Let me know if this resolves your issue!

ChatGPT said:

Looking at your vercel.json and the project structure, there are a couple of potential issues that might cause the "Page Not Found" error when refreshing your SPA (Single Page Application).

Heres how you can fix the issue:

Steps to Fix "Page Not Found" on Refresh:

  1. Ensure Correct Routing for SPA: You already have a rewrite rule in place for handling routes ("/(.*)" -> "/index.html"), which is correct. However, you also have a routes block that might conflict with the rewrites block. Specifically, the routes block may cause issues because both are trying to handle requests to /(.*).

    To fix this, remove the routes block since you already have the rewrites block for handling the routing.

    Updated vercel.json:

    json
    {
  "version": 2,
  "builds": [
    {
      "src": "server/server.mjs",
      "use": "@vercel/node"
    },
    {
      "src": "index.html",
      "use": "@vercel/static-build"
    }
  ],
  "rewrites": [
    {
      "source": "/(.*)",
      "destination": "/index.html"
    }
  ]
}

  2. Server-Side Transpiling: Ensure that the server-side code (server.mjs) correctly handles requests and isnt interfering with your React app's routes. Since you are using Vercel for both the server and the client, make sure your server handles API requests and your static client-side routing does not interfere with each other.

    Key Notes:

    • The rewrites block ensures all client-side routes are directed to index.html for React to handle.
    • Your API routes (/api/*) should be handled separately via the server code (server/server.mjs).
    • The server-side API code (server/server.mjs) should handle only /api/* routes to avoid collisions with the front-end routes.

  3. Vite Configuration for SPA: You are using Vite as the build tool, so ensure that Vite is configured to correctly handle SPA routing in development and production modes. Typically, Vite should already handle this automatically, but double-check the vite.config.ts file for correct settings.

    Make sure that the vite.config.ts includes a build setup like:

    ts
    import { defineConfig } from 'vite';
import react from '@vitejs/plugin-react';

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [react()],
  build: {
    outDir: 'dist',
  },
  server: {
    historyApiFallback: true, // Enable this for proper SPA routing in development
  }
});

    This ensures that routes are properly handled during development.

  4. Deploy the Fix:

    • After making these changes, commit them to your Git repository and push to trigger a new Vercel deployment.
    • Check if the refresh issue is resolved.

Additional Debugging:

  • API Routes: Ensure that the API endpoints (/api/*) defined in server/server.mjs are not conflicting with the client-side routes. Your API endpoints are correctly handled in your Vercel setup under /api/(.*).

  • Static Files: If you are using Vercel to serve static files from /public, ensure that the paths are properly structured and that there is no conflict with other routes.

Let me know if this resolves your issue or if you need more specific debugging for a particular part of the project!

ChatGPT said:

The error you're encountering suggests that historyApiFallback is not a valid option for the server configuration in Vite. The reason is that Vite uses a different mechanism for handling fallback routes for SPAs compared to older tools like Webpack.

To fix this, we need to remove historyApiFallback and let Vite handle the fallback routing automatically, as it already does by default for Single Page Applications.

Heres how to properly handle routing in Vite for SPAs:

Fixing Vite SPA Configuration

  1. Remove historyApiFallback: You dont need to manually configure historyApiFallback in Vite. Vite already handles SPA fallback behavior out of the box.

  2. Ensure Correct Vite Configuration: Heres a simplified vite.config.ts that works for your React project:

    ts
    import { defineConfig } from 'vite';
import react from '@vitejs/plugin-react';

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [react()],
  build: {
    outDir: 'dist',  // Output directory for production build
  },
  server: {
    open: true,      // Automatically open the browser on server start
    port: 3000,      // Specify port if necessary
  }
});

  3. Check Vercel Deployment Configuration: Your Vercel configuration (vercel.json) should handle the routing fallback for the SPA by using the rewrite rule like this:

    json
    {
  "version": 2,
  "builds": [
    {
      "src": "server/server.mjs",
      "use": "@vercel/node"
    },
    {
      "src": "index.html",
      "use": "@vercel/static-build"
    }
  ],
  "rewrites": [
    {
      "source": "/(.*)",
      "destination": "/index.html"
    }
  ]
}

  4. React Router Setup (If applicable): If you are using React Router for client-side routing, ensure you have it set up to handle all routes appropriately. You may need to use a Switch with Route in your React code to manage different routes within your app:

    tsx
    import { BrowserRouter as Router, Route, Switch } from 'react-router-dom';
import HomePage from './components/Home/HomePage';
import JoinMeeting from './components/Home/JoinMeeting';

function App() {
  return (
    <Router>
      <Switch>
        <Route exact path="/" component={HomePage} />
        <Route path="/join" component={JoinMeeting} />
        {/* Add other routes here */}
      </Switch>
    </Router>
  );
}

export default App;

ChatGPT said:

The 404 Not Found error indicates that Vercel is not properly handling client-side routing for your Single Page Application (SPA). React Router is handling navigation on the client side, but when the page is refreshed or accessed directly (e.g., /home), Vercel attempts to resolve the route on the server, leading to the 404 error.

To fix this issue, you need to ensure that Vercel redirects all requests to your index.html, allowing React Router to handle the routing. This is done by setting up a rewrite rule in your vercel.json file.

Heres how you can fix the issue:

1. Fixing Vercel Configuration:

Update your vercel.json to correctly redirect all client-side routes back to index.html:

json
{
  "version": 2,
  "builds": [
    {
      "src": "server/server.mjs",
      "use": "@vercel/node"
    },
    {
      "src": "index.html",
      "use": "@vercel/static-build"
    }
  ],
  "routes": [
    {
      "src": "/api/(.*)",
      "dest": "/server/server.mjs",
      "methods": ["GET", "POST", "PUT", "DELETE", "PATCH", "OPTIONS"],
      "headers": {
        "Access-Control-Allow-Origin": "*"
      }
    },
    {
      "src": "/(.*)",
      "dest": "/index.html"
    }
  ],
  "rewrites": [
    {
      "source": "/(.*)",
      "destination": "/index.html"
    }
  ]
}

2. Explanation:

  • The "routes" section ensures that any API routes (those prefixed with /api/) are handled by your server-side logic in server.mjs.
  • The src: "/(.*)" rule matches all other routes (such as /home, /create-meeting, etc.) and redirects them to index.html, allowing React Router to handle the routing on the client side.

3. React Router Configuration:

Your React Router setup looks good, and the routes are defined correctly in App.tsx. Heres a quick review:

  • / route displays the LoginPage.
  • /home displays the HomePage.
  • /signup, /create-meeting, /join-meeting, and /logs display the respective components.

Ensure that the browser's address bar shows the correct paths and that navigating between pages works fine.

4. Testing Locally:

  • Ensure that your local development server is correctly serving the app using the vite.config.ts setup.
  • You can test refreshing pages like /home locally before deploying.

5. Re-deploy to Vercel:

After updating vercel.json:

  • Commit the changes.
  • Push to your repository.
  • Vercel will automatically redeploy your app.

Once deployed, access the /home, /create-meeting, /join-meeting, and /logs routes directly or refresh the pages to verify that they work without returning a 404 error.

Let me know if that resolves the issue!

json

Since youre getting a 404 Not Found when refreshing or navigating directly to routes like /home, it indicates that the server doesnt know how to handle these routes because SPAs rely on client-side routing.

Heres a refined approach to solve the issue:

1. Re-check vercel.json Configuration

You need to make sure Vercel serves the index.html file for all routes in your React app. Lets update the vercel.json to handle this:

json

  "version": 2,
  "builds": [

      "src": "server/server.mjs",
      "use": "@vercel/node"
    },
    {
      "src": "dist/**",  // Ensure Vercel serves from the dist folder

      "headers": {
        "Access-Control-Allow-Origin": "*"
      }
    },
    {
      "handle": "filesystem"
    },
    {
      "src": "/(.*)",  // This matches all routes
      "dest": "/index.html"  // Serve the index.html file for all routes
    }
  ]
}

Explanation:

  • The "src": "/(.*)", "dest": "/index.html" line ensures that for any route that isnt handled by the filesystem or API, Vercel will serve the index.html file, allowing React Router to take over.
  • "handle": "filesystem" makes sure any static files (like images, CSS, JS) are served correctly before falling back to index.html for client-side routing.

To integrate your existing API functions from the api folder and use server.mjs to handle API requests, you should:

  1. Set Up server.mjs to Handle API Requests
  2. Ensure api Functions are Properly Defined

Here's a step-by-step guide to help you:

1. Update server.mjs

In server.mjs, you should set up a basic server to handle API requests. If you're using Express.js or a similar framework, it will look something like this:

Example server.mjs using Express:

js
import express from 'express';
import { json, urlencoded } from 'express';
import { fileURLToPath } from 'url';
import path from 'path';

// Create an Express application
const app = express();

// Middleware
app.use(json());
app.use(urlencoded({ extended: true }));

// Serve static files from the dist directory
app.use(express.static(path.join(process.cwd(), 'dist')));

// Route for API endpoints
app.use('/api', (req, res) => {
  const apiPath = `./api${req.path}.js`;
  
  // Dynamically import the API function based on the request path
  import(apiPath)
    .then(module => {
      const handler = module.default;
      if (handler) {
        handler(req, res);
      } else {
        res.status(404).send('Not Found');
      }
    })
    .catch(() => {
      res.status(404).send('Not Found');
    });
});

// Handle client-side routing (catch-all for SPA)
app.get('/*', (req, res) => {
  res.sendFile(path.join(process.cwd(), 'dist', 'index.html'));
});

// Start the server
const port = process.env.PORT || 3000;
app.listen(port, () => {
  console.log(`Server running on port ${port}`);
});

2. Ensure API Functions are Correctly Defined

Each API function file in the api folder should export a default handler function. For example:

api/login.js:

js

  // Your API logic here

To properly handle API requests in server.mjs, you'll need to ensure that it correctly imports and executes functions from the api folder. Heres how you can set up server.mjs to work with API functions, like api/login.js.

Example api/login.js

Make sure your api/login.js file exports a handler function like this:

js
// api/login.js
export default async function handler(req, res) {
  // Your login logic here

}

Configuring server.mjs

You need to set up server.mjs to route requests to the appropriate API handlers. Below is an example configuration using Express:

server.mjs:

js
import express from 'express';
import { json, urlencoded } from 'express';
import path from 'path';
import fs from 'fs';
import { fileURLToPath } from 'url';

// Create an Express application
const app = express();

// Middleware
app.use(json());
app.use(urlencoded({ extended: true }));

// Serve static files from the dist directory
app.use(express.static(path.join(process.cwd(), 'dist')));

// Dynamically import API functions based on request path
app.use('/api', async (req, res) => {
  const apiPath = path.join(process.cwd(), 'api', `${req.path.slice(1)}.js`);
  
  try {
    if (fs.existsSync(apiPath)) {
      const { default: handler } = await import(apiPath);
      handler(req, res);
    } else {
      res.status(404).send('Not Found');
    }
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error handling API request:', error);
    res.status(500).send('Internal Server Error');
  }
});

// Handle client-side routing (catch-all for SPA)
app.get('/*', (req, res) => {
  res.sendFile(path.join(process.cwd(), 'dist', 'index.html'));
});

// Start the server
const port = process.env.PORT || 3000;
app.listen(port, () => {
  console.log(`Server running on port ${port}`);
});

Key Points in server.mjs

  1. Static Files Serving:

    js
    app.use(express.static(path.join(process.cwd(), 'dist')));

    This serves your static files from the dist directory.

  2. Dynamic API Import:

    js
    app.use('/api', async (req, res) => {
  const apiPath = path.join(process.cwd(), 'api', `${req.path.slice(1)}.js`);
  
  try {
    if (fs.existsSync(apiPath)) {
      const { default: handler } = await import(apiPath);
      handler(req, res);
    } else {
      res.status(404).send('Not Found');
    }
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Error handling API request:', error);
    res.status(500).send('Internal Server Error');
  }
});

    This dynamically imports the API handler based on the request path and executes it.

  3. Client-Side Routing:

    js
    app.get('/*', (req, res) => {
  res.sendFile(path.join(process.cwd(), 'dist', 'index.html'));
});

    This ensures that client-side routes are handled by serving the index.html file for any non-API requests.

Based on your provided API files, you'll need to adjust server.mjs to correctly handle these API routes. Since you are using Firebase and various API endpoints, you should set up your server to route requests to the corresponding files.

Here's how you can set up server.mjs to handle the API requests:

  1. Import necessary modules
  2. Set up routes for your API endpoints

Here's a sample server.mjs that should work for your setup:

javascript
import { createServer } from 'http';
import { parse } from 'url';
import { IncomingMessage, request, requestListener } from 'http';
import { join } from 'path';
import fs from 'fs';
import { fileURLToPath } from 'url';
import { Handler } from '@vercel/node';

const __filename = fileURLToPath(import.meta.url);
const __dirname = path.dirname(__filename);

const server = createServer((req, res) => {
  const parsedUrl = parse(req.url, true);
  const { pathname } = parsedUrl;

  // Route API requests
  if (pathname.startsWith('/api/')) {
    const apiFile = join(__dirname, `api${pathname}.js`);
    if (fs.existsSync(apiFile)) {
      const handler = require(apiFile).default;
      return handler(req, res);
    } else {
      res.statusCode = 404;
      res.end('Not Found');
      return;
    }
  }

  // Serve static files
  if (pathname === '/' || pathname.startsWith('/assets/')) {
    const filePath = join(__dirname, 'dist', pathname === '/' ? 'index.html' : pathname);
    fs.readFile(filePath, (err, data) => {
      if (err) {
        res.statusCode = 404;
        res.end('Not Found');
        return;
      }
      res.setHeader('Content-Type', getContentType(filePath));
      res.end(data);
    });
    return;
  }

  // 404 for other routes
  res.statusCode = 404;
  res.end('Not Found');
});

// Helper function to determine content type
function getContentType(filePath) {
  const extname = path.extname(filePath);
  switch (extname) {
    case '.js': return 'application/javascript';
    case '.css': return 'text/css';
    case '.html': return 'text/html';
    case '.svg': return 'image/svg+xml';
    default: return 'application/octet-stream';
  }
}

server.listen(3000, () => {
  console.log('Server running on http://localhost:3000');
});

export default server;

Key Points:

  • API Routing: The server.mjs handles routing requests starting with /api/ to the corresponding files in the api directory.
  • Static File Serving: Requests for static files (like the index.html or assets) are served from the dist folder.
  • 404 Handling: Returns a 404 response for unknown routes or files.

Ensure that:

  1. Your API files are located in the api directory.
  2. The dist directory contains your static assets and index.html.
  3. You deploy server.mjs correctly on Vercel with this setup.

If you have other issues or need further customization, let me know!

If you're deploying to Vercel, you should adapt your server code to work with Vercel's serverless function environment. Vercel doesn't use traditional server instances like you might set up with http.createServer. Instead, it expects you to use serverless functions that are deployed to their infrastructure.

Heres how you can adapt your code for Vercel:

  1. Serverless Functions: Vercel serverless functions are placed in the api directory and follow the format api/[functionName].js (or .ts for TypeScript). Each file exports a handler function.

  2. Routing: Vercel automatically handles routing based on the file names and paths in the api directory.

  3. Static File Serving: For static files, you should use the public directory. Vercel automatically serves files from this directory.

Heres an example of how to adapt your code for Vercel:

  1. Remove Manual Server Creation: Remove the http.createServer and related code. Vercel automatically handles routing and server creation.

  2. API Route Files: Place your API route files in the api directory. For example, api/login.js, api/fetchLogs.js, etc.

  3. Static Files: Place static files like HTML, CSS, and JS in the public directory. Vercel will serve these files automatically.

Example api/login.js

javascript
import { getFirestore, collection, query, where, getDocs } from "firebase/firestore";
import { initializeApp } from "firebase/app";
import dotenv from "dotenv";

dotenv.config();

const firebaseConfig = {
  apiKey: process.env.FIREBASE_API_KEY,
  authDomain: process.env.FIREBASE_AUTH_DOMAIN,
  projectId: process.env.FIREBASE_PROJECT_ID,
  storageBucket: process.env.FIREBASE_STORAGE_BUCKET,
  messagingSenderId: process.env.FIREBASE_MESSAGING_SENDER_ID,
  appId: process.env.FIREBASE_APP_ID,
  measurementId: process.env.FIREBASE_MEASUREMENT_ID,
};

const firebaseApp = initializeApp(firebaseConfig);
const db = getFirestore(firebaseApp);

export default async function handler(req, res) {
  const { email, password } = req.body;
  try {
    if (!email || !password) {
      return res.status(400).json({ error: "Email and password are required" });
    }

    const userQuery = query(
      collection(db, "users"),
      where("email", "==", email)
    );
    const querySnapshot = await getDocs(userQuery);

    if (querySnapshot.empty) {
      return res.status(401).json({ error: "Invalid email or password" });
    }

    const userDoc = querySnapshot.docs[0];
    const userData = userDoc.data();
    const { password: hashedPassword, userId, token } = userData;

    const passwordMatch = await bcrypt.compare(password, hashedPassword);

    if (!passwordMatch) {
      return res.status(401).json({ error: "Invalid email or password" });
    }

    res.status(200).json({ userId, token });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error during login:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ error: "Internal server error" });
  }
}

Example public/index.html

html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">

</head>
<body>
  <h1>Hello, world!</h1>
  <script src="/assets/script.js"></script>
</body>
</html>

Example vercel.json

This file configures Vercel's build and deployment settings.

json
{
  "version": 2,
  "builds": [
    { "src": "api/**/*.js", "use": "@vercel/node" },
    { "src": "public/**/*", "use": "@vercel/static" }
  ],
  "routes": [
    { "src": "/api/(.*)", "dest": "/api/$1" },
    { "src": "/(.*)", "dest": "/public/$1" }
  ]
}

With this setup, your Vercel deployment will handle API requests through the api directory and serve static files from the public directory.

    javascript

import { initializeApp } from "firebase/app";

  try {
    if (!email || !password) {
      return res.status(400).json({ error: "Email and password are required" });
    }

    const userQuery = query(
      collection(db, "users"),
      where("email", "==", email)
    );
    const querySnapshot = await getDocs(userQuery);

    if (querySnapshot.empty) {
      return res.status(401).json({ error: "Invalid email or password" });
    }

    const userDoc = querySnapshot.docs[0];
    const userData = userDoc.data();

    const passwordMatch = await bcrypt.compare(password, hashedPassword);

    if (!passwordMatch) {
      return res.status(401).json({ error: "Invalid email or password" });
    }

    res.status(200).json({ userId, token });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error during login:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ error: "Internal server error" });
  }

ChatGPT said:

In the context of deploying to Vercel, you generally dont need a server.mjs file if you are using Vercel's serverless functions. Vercel's platform is designed to handle serverless functions and static file serving out of the box, which means you don't need to manually create and manage an HTTP server like you would with a traditional Node.js server.

Heres a summary of what you need to focus on for Vercel:

  1. API Routes: Place your API route files in the api directory. Each file should export a function that handles HTTP requests and responses, as shown in the previous examples.

  2. Static Files: Place your static files (e.g., HTML, CSS, JS) in the public directory. Vercel automatically serves files from this directory.

  3. Configuration File (vercel.json): This file specifies how Vercel should handle your deployment. It tells Vercel where your serverless functions are and how to serve static files.

If you were using a custom server (like in your server.mjs file) for handling requests, Vercels serverless functions replace the need for this custom server.

Heres how you can adapt your project without the server.mjs file:

  1. Move Logic to API Routes:

    • Place the route handlers you had in server.mjs into files in the api directory.

  2. Static File Handling:

    • Ensure your static assets are in the public directory. Vercel automatically serves these.

  3. Remove server.mjs:

    • You dont need to manually start an HTTP server or handle routing in a server.mjs file. Vercel will handle API routes and static file serving based on your vercel.json configuration.

Example of vercel.json for your setup:

json
{
  "version": 2,
  "builds": [
    { "src": "api/**/*.js", "use": "@vercel/node" },
    { "src": "public/**/*", "use": "@vercel/static" }
  ],
  "routes": [
    { "src": "/api/(.*)", "dest": "/api/$1" },
    { "src": "/(.*)", "dest": "/public/$1" }
  ]
}

In this setup:

  • API Routes are handled by serverless functions defined in the api directory.
  • Static Files are served from the public directory.

By following this structure, you can leverage Vercels serverless functions and automatic static file serving, simplifying your deployment process.

You said:
what do you mean by the statice file ?
ChatGPT said:

Static files are files that are served directly to the client (browser) without any server-side processing or dynamic generation. They include:

  • HTML files: The structure of your web pages.
  • CSS files: Stylesheets that define the look and feel of your pages.
  • JavaScript files: Client-side scripts that provide interactive functionality.
  • Images: PNG, JPEG, SVG, etc.
  • Fonts: Custom fonts used in your website.

In a web application, static files are essential for the user interface and are typically stored in a specific directory, such as public or static. These files are served as-is by the web server or hosting platform.

For Vercel:

  1. Public Directory: Place your static files in a directory named public (or whatever you configure in vercel.json). Vercel automatically serves files from this directory at the root of your deployment. For example, if you have a file public/index.html, it will be accessible at the root URL of your deployed site.

  2. Serving Static Files: You dont need to explicitly handle static files in your code. Vercel will automatically handle requests for static files based on their location in the public directory.

Example Directory Structure:

swift
project-root/
 api/
    some-endpoint.js
    another-endpoint.js
 public/
    index.html
    styles.css
    script.js
    images/
        logo.png
 vercel.json

In this structure:

  • Files in public/ will be served directly, such as index.html being accessible at the root URL.
  • API routes in api/ will be handled by Vercel serverless functions.

By organizing your files this way, you ensure that static files are efficiently served by Vercel, while dynamic functionality is handled by your serverless functions.

You said:
Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 404 ()Understand this error
ChatGPT said:

The "Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 404" error means that a resource (like a file, API endpoint, or other asset) your web page or application is trying to access was not found on the server. Here are some common causes and how to troubleshoot them:

1. Incorrect File Path or URL

  • Issue: The file path or URL might be incorrect. This could be due to a typo, incorrect directory structure, or wrong URL format.
  • Solution: Double-check the paths used in your HTML, CSS, or JavaScript files. Ensure they correctly point to the files or endpoints you intend to access. For example, if you're trying to load styles.css, make sure it's located in the public directory and referenced correctly in your HTML.

2. File Not Deployed

  • Issue: The file or resource may not have been deployed properly or is missing from the deployed environment.
  • Solution: Verify that the file exists in the public directory and was included in the deployment. Check your deployment logs to see if there were any errors related to missing files.

3. API Endpoint Issues

  • Issue: The API endpoint might be incorrect, or the serverless function may not be configured properly.
  • Solution: Check the API routes you have defined in your api directory and ensure they match the URLs being requested. Verify that the functions are deployed correctly and can handle the requests. You can also test the endpoints directly in your browser or a tool like Postman.

4. Server Configuration

  • Issue: There might be an issue with server configuration that prevents certain resources from being served correctly.
  • Solution: Ensure that your server or hosting configuration is set up to handle static files and API routes correctly. In Vercel, for instance, you typically don't need custom server code to serve static files or handle API routes, as it automatically manages these aspects.

5. Case Sensitivity

  • Issue: File names and paths are case-sensitive on most servers.
  • Solution: Ensure that the case of file names in your code matches exactly with the case of the file names in your deployment.

6. Check Network Requests

  • Solution: Use the browsers developer tools (usually accessed by pressing F12 or right-clicking and selecting "Inspect") to view the network requests. This can help you see which request is failing and might provide additional details on why it's returning a 404 error.

Example Scenario:

  • HTML Reference:

    html
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="/styles.css">
<script src="/script.js"></script>

  • File Location:

    arduino
    project-root/
 public/
     styles.css
     script.js

If the styles.css file is not found, ensure:

  • It exists in the public directory.
  • Its referenced correctly in your HTML file.

If an API endpoint like /api/login is returning 404:

  • Ensure the file api/login.js exists.
  • Verify the function handler is properly exported as default.
  • Check that your API route configuration matches.

By carefully checking these aspects, you can usually identify and fix the cause of a 404 error.

Heres a basic example of what your vercel.json configuration might look like for your setup:

json
{
  "version": 2,
  "builds": [
    {
      "src": "src/**/*.ts",
      "use": "@vercel/node",

    {

      "dest": "/src/$1"
    }
  ],

  }
}

Explanation:

  1. Builds:

    • The second build step handles static files in the public directory using @vercel/static.

  2. Routes:

Notes:

  • Path Adjustments: Ensure that the paths in the src and dest fields are correctly aligned with your directory structure. If your static files are not being served correctly, double-check the paths.

ChatGPT said:

Your vercel.json configuration looks almost correct, but there are a few adjustments and clarifications needed to ensure everything works properly, especially for handling API routes and static files.

Heres how you can adjust the configuration for the setup you've described:

1. API Handlers

Your API handlers are located in the api directory. For Vercel to handle these as serverless functions, you dont need a custom server.mjs file. Instead, Vercel will automatically treat files in the api directory as serverless functions.

So, you should make sure your vercel.json properly routes API requests to these functions.

Updated vercel.json

json
{
  "version": 2,
  "builds": [
    {
      "src": "src/**/*", // Include all files under the "src" directory
      "use": "@vercel/static-build", // Use Vercel's static build for client-side files
      "config": {
        "buildCommand": "vite build", // Use Vite to build the production bundle
        "outputDirectory": "dist", // Ensure this matches the output directory of Vite build
        "env": {
          "VERCEL": true
        }
      }
    },
    {
      "src": "api/**/*.js", // Include serverless functions (API handlers)
      "use": "@vercel/node"
    }
  ],
  "routes": [
    { "src": "/favicon.ico", "dest": "/favicon.ico" },
    { "src": "/api/(.*)", "dest": "/api/$1.js" }, // Route API requests to the serverless functions
    { "src": "/(.*)", "dest": "/index.html" } // Catch-all route for client-side routing
  ],
  "rewrites": [],
  "env": {
    "PUBLIC_API_URL": "/api" // Reference to the base URL for API routes
  }
}

Key Points

  1. API Routes: The api/**/*.js build target will pick up the files in the api directory and deploy them as serverless functions. Vercel will automatically handle these if they're placed under the api directory.

  2. Client-Side Files: For static files served from the dist directory (generated by Vite), ensure the outputDirectory in the buildCommand configuration matches the directory where Vite outputs the build files. This is usually dist, but check your Vite configuration if it's different.

  3. Routing:

    • The src /api/(.*) route ensures that API requests are correctly forwarded to the serverless functions.
    • The src /(.*) route is a catch-all route for client-side routing, serving index.html for any route not matched by previous rules.

  4. Static Files: Ensure that the static files are correctly included in the build output directory and referenced properly.

Serverless Functions

You dont need to create a server.mjs file to handle API requests. Instead, ensure your API handlers in the api directory are properly exported and structured as Vercel expects:

For example, a file api/login.js might look like this:

js
export default function handler(req, res) {
  // Handle the request here
  res.status(200).json({ message: "Hello from login API" });
}

Testing Locally

Before deploying, ensure you test locally to verify the build and routing:

bash
npm run build  # Ensure Vite builds the static files correctly

You can also use a local server to mimic Vercels environment:

bash
npx vercel dev

This command will run a local development server that simulates Vercels deployment environment, allowing you to test your API routes and static files.

By making these adjustments, your deployment should correctly handle both static files and API routes.

You said:
how to deploy vite+react project on github with server?
ChatGPT said:

Deploying a Vite + React project with a server (e.g., an Express server or API endpoints) to GitHub Pages or a similar static hosting service can be a bit tricky because GitHub Pages primarily supports static sites and doesn't support server-side code directly.

However, you can deploy a Vite + React project with a server to platforms that support full-stack applications, such as Vercel, Netlify, or Heroku. Heres a general approach for deploying such a project to Vercel:

Step-by-Step Deployment to Vercel

  1. Prepare Your Project

    Make sure your project structure is as follows:

    perl
     my-project
     api        # Serverless functions
         handler.js
     public     # Static assets
     src        # React app
     .vercelignore # Optional, to ignore files in Vercel
     vercel.json  # Vercel configuration
     package.json
     vite.config.ts
     index.html

  2. Set Up Vite Configuration

    Ensure your vite.config.ts (or vite.config.js) is properly configured to build the project into a dist directory:

    ts
    // vite.config.ts
import { defineConfig } from 'vite';
import react from '@vitejs/plugin-react';

export default defineConfig({
  plugins: [react()],
  build: {
    outDir: 'dist' // Ensure this matches the output directory in your vercel.json
  }
});

  3. Configure Vercel

    Create a vercel.json file in the root of your project to configure Vercel deployments:

    json
    {
  "version": 2,
  "builds": [
    {
      "src": "src/**/*",
      "use": "@vercel/static-build",
      "config": {
        "buildCommand": "vite build",
        "outputDirectory": "dist"
      }
    },
    {
      "src": "api/**/*.js",
      "use": "@vercel/node"
    }
  ],
  "routes": [
    { "src": "/api/(.*)", "dest": "/api/$1.js" },
    { "src": "/(.*)", "dest": "/index.html" }
  ]
}

  4. Create API Endpoints

    For Vercel serverless functions, ensure your API files are in the api directory and follow this format:

    js
    // api/handler.js
export default function handler(req, res) {
  res.status(200).json({ message: "Hello from API" });
}

  5. Deploy to Vercel

    • Push Your Project to GitHub:

      Make sure your project is committed and pushed to GitHub.

    • Connect Your GitHub Repository to Vercel:

      1. Go to Vercel.
      2. Click on "New Project."
      3. Import your GitHub repository.
      4. Configure the build settings if needed (Vercel usually detects the settings automatically).

    • Deploy:

      Vercel will automatically build and deploy your project based on the vercel.json configuration. You can view the deployment status and preview your app through the Vercel dashboard.

Deploying to GitHub Pages

If you specifically need to deploy to GitHub Pages (which only supports static files), you will need to exclude server-side code and handle server-side functionality separately. You could deploy the React frontend to GitHub Pages and host the server elsewhere, like on Heroku or Vercel.

  1. Build Your React App

    Use Vite to build your React app:

    bash
    npm run build

    This will generate a dist directory with static files.

  2. Configure GitHub Pages

    • In your package.json, add a homepage field:

      json
      "homepage": "https://<username>.github.io/<repository-name>"

    • Add a script to deploy to GitHub Pages:

      json
      "scripts": {
  "deploy": "gh-pages -d dist"
}

    • Install gh-pages:

      bash
      npm install --save-dev gh-pages

    • Deploy:

      bash
      npm run deploy

This will deploy your static React app to GitHub Pages. Ensure your server is deployed separately and accessible if needed.

Example Configuration

Heres a refined example of a vercel.json configuration for a Vite + React project:

json
{
  "version": 2,
  "builds": [
    {
      "src": "package.json",
      "use": "@vercel/static-build",
      "config": {
        "buildCommand": "vite build",
        "outputDirectory": "dist"
      }
    },
    {
      "src": "api/**/*.js",
      "use": "@vercel/node"
    }
  ],
  "routes": [
    // Route for API endpoints
    { "src": "/api/(.*)", "dest": "/api/$1.js" },
    // Route for static files and client-side routing
    { "src": "/static/(.*)", "dest": "/static/$1" },
    // Catch-all route for single-page application
    { "src": "/(.*)", "dest": "/index.html" }
  ]
}

7. Check Server Logs

how to add simulator on vs code to see the site on mobile ?
ChatGPT said:

To view and test your website on mobile devices using Visual Studio Code (VS Code), you have several options. Heres a detailed guide on how to set up a mobile simulator:

1. Use Browser DevTools Mobile Emulator

Most modern browsers, including Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge, have built-in mobile emulators. This is a quick way to see how your site looks on various mobile devices.

Google Chrome:

  1. Open Your Site in Chrome:

    • Launch Chrome and open your site by typing http://localhost:3000 (or whatever port you're using) in the address bar.

  2. Open DevTools:

    • Press Ctrl+Shift+I (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+Option+I (Mac) to open DevTools.

  3. Toggle Device Toolbar:

    • Click the Toggle device toolbar button (or press Ctrl+Shift+M/Cmd+Shift+M). This will switch to a mobile view.

  4. Select a Device:

    • Use the device dropdown menu in the toolbar to select different mobile devices and screen sizes.

Microsoft Edge:

  1. Open Your Site in Edge:

    • Launch Edge and open your site.

  2. Open DevTools:

    • Press F12 or Ctrl+Shift+I (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+Option+I (Mac) to open DevTools.

  3. Toggle Device Toolbar:

    • Click the Toggle device emulation button (or press Ctrl+Shift+M/Cmd+Shift+M).

  4. Select a Device:

    • Choose from various device options to see how your site performs on different screen sizes.

2. Use VS Code Extensions

There are several VS Code extensions that can help with mobile emulation, though they might not be as comprehensive as browser tools. Extensions can assist with responsive design but may not fully emulate a mobile environment.

Extensions:

  • Live Server:

    • Allows you to launch a local development server with live reloading. Useful for quickly viewing changes in your browser.
    bash
    ext install ritwickdey.liveServer

  • Responsive Design Mode:

    • Provides some basic tools for responsive design, though it's more limited compared to browser DevTools.
    bash
    ext install tht13.responsive-design-mode

3. Use Mobile Device Emulators

For a more comprehensive simulation, consider using standalone mobile emulators. These can be particularly useful if you need to test specific mobile features.

Using Android Emulator:

  1. Install Android Studio:

    • Download and install Android Studio from the official site.

  2. Set Up an Emulator:

    • Open Android Studio and go to Tools > AVD Manager.
    • Create a new virtual device and choose a device profile.
    • Start the emulator.

  3. Access Your Site:

    • Open the browser within the emulator and navigate to http://localhost:3000 or your development URL.

Using Xcode Simulator (macOS only):

  1. Install Xcode:

    • Download and install Xcode from the Mac App Store.

  2. Set Up an iOS Simulator:

    • Open Xcode, go to Xcode > Preferences > Components, and download the required simulator.

  3. Launch the Simulator:

    • Go to Xcode > Open Developer Tool > Simulator.

  4. Access Your Site:

    • Open Safari within the simulator and navigate to http://localhost:3000 or your development URL.

4. Live Server in VS Code

To quickly preview changes with live reloading, you can use the Live Server extension in VS Code.

  1. Install Live Server:

    bash
    ext install ritwickdey.liveServer

  2. Open Your Project:

    • Open your project folder in VS Code.

  3. Start Live Server:

    • Right-click on your index.html file (or any other file you want to preview) and select Open with Live Server. This will open your site in the default browser.

  4. Use Browser DevTools:

    • Follow the browser DevTools method mentioned above to view and test on mobile.

Summary

  • For quick mobile views, use the mobile emulation features built into modern browsers like Chrome or Edge.
  • For live reloading and local development, use the Live Server extension in VS Code.
  • For comprehensive mobile testing, consider using dedicated mobile emulators like Android Studio or Xcode Simulator.

By following these steps, you can effectively test and simulate your website on mobile devices to ensure a responsive and functional design.

    setLoading(false);
    return;
  }

  try {
    const response = await fetch(
      `https://${server_ip}/api/fetchlogs?userId=${user.id}`,
      {
        method: "GET",
        headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
      }
    );
    if (!response.ok) {
      const errorText = await response.text();
      console.error(
        `Failed to fetch logs: ${response.status} - ${response.statusText}\n${errorText}`
      );
      throw new Error(
        `Failed to fetch logs: ${response.status} - ${response.statusText}\n${errorText}`
      );
    }
    const data = await response.json();
    setLogs(data);
    setFilteredLogs(data);
  } catch (err: any) {
    console.error("Error fetching logs:", err.message);
    setError(`Failed to fetch logs: ${err.message}`);
  } finally {
    setLoading(false);
  }
};

6. Ensure State Updates Are Triggered

Make sure that setFilteredLogs is being called after the search term changes. If searchTerm is empty, the filter should return all logs.

7. Check filteredLogs Usage

Ensure that filteredLogs is used correctly in the component:

javascript
const currentLogs = filteredLogs.slice(indexOfFirstLog, indexOfLastLog);

This ensures that pagination and filtering are working together.

8. Potential Issues

  • Data Format Mismatch: Ensure that the data format you receive from the server matches the format expected in your filter logic.
  • Component Re-renders: Ensure the component re-renders correctly when searchTerm or logs changes.

By going through these steps, you should be able to pinpoint where the search mechanism might be failing and address the issue accordingly.

Here's the updated code with enhancements and debugging to ensure the search functionality works as expected. This version includes logging and checks to help diagnose any issues:

Updated Logs.tsx

typescript
import React, { useEffect, useState } from "react";
import { useVideoClient } from "../VideoClientContext";
import "@fortawesome/fontawesome-free/css/all.min.css"; // Import FontAwesome CSS
import logo from "../../assets/HomePage/logo.png";
import "./Logs.css";
import home from "../../assets/HomePage/home.png";
import { useNavigate } from "react-router-dom";

const Logs: React.FC = () => {
  const { user } = useVideoClient(); // Get user from context
  const [logs, setLogs] = useState<string[]>([]);
  const [filteredLogs, setFilteredLogs] = useState<string[]>([]);
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState<boolean>(true);
  const [error, setError] = useState<string | null>(null);
  const [searchTerm, setSearchTerm] = useState<string>("");
  const [currentPage, setCurrentPage] = useState<number>(1);
  const logsPerPage = 6;
  const navigate = useNavigate(); // Initialize useNavigate hook
  const server_ip = "rmvideocall.vercel.app";

  useEffect(() => {
    const fetchLogs = async () => {
      if (!user) {
        setError("User not logged in");
        setLoading(false);
        return;
      }

      try {
        const response = await fetch(
          `https://${server_ip}/api/fetchlogs?userId=${user.id}`,
          {
            method: "GET",
            headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
          }
        );
        if (!response.ok) {
          const errorText = await response.text();
          console.error(
            `Failed to fetch logs: ${response.status} - ${response.statusText}\n${errorText}`
          );
          throw new Error(
            `Failed to fetch logs: ${response.status} - ${response.statusText}\n${errorText}`
          );
        }
        const data = await response.json();
        setLogs(data);
        setFilteredLogs(data);
      } catch (err: any) {
        console.error("Error fetching logs:", err.message);
        setError(`Failed to fetch logs: ${err.message}`);
      } finally {
        setLoading(false);
      }
    };

    fetchLogs();
  }, [user]);

  const handleLogout = () => {
    console.log("Navigating to home...");
    navigate("/home");
  };

  useEffect(() => {
    // Filter logs based on search term
    console.log("Search term:", searchTerm);
    console.log("Logs before filtering:", logs);

    const results = logs.filter((log) =>
      log.toLowerCase().includes(searchTerm.toLowerCase())
    );

    console.log("Filtered results:", results);
    setFilteredLogs(results);
    setCurrentPage(1); // Reset to first page when search term changes
  }, [searchTerm, logs]);

  const indexOfLastLog = currentPage * logsPerPage;
  const indexOfFirstLog = indexOfLastLog - logsPerPage;
  const currentLogs = filteredLogs.slice(indexOfFirstLog, indexOfLastLog);

  const handleSearchChange = (event: React.ChangeEvent<HTMLInputElement>) => {
    setSearchTerm(event.target.value);
  };

  const handlePageChange = (pageNumber: number) => {
    setCurrentPage(pageNumber);
  };

  if (loading) return <div>Loading logs...</div>;
  if (error) return <div>Error: {error}</div>;

  return (
    <div className="logs-container">
      <nav className="navbar">
        <div className="brand-logo">
          <img src={logo} alt="Logo" />
        </div>
        <img
          src={home}
          onClick={handleLogout}
          alt="Exit"
          className="exit-icon"
        />
      </nav>
      <h1 className="title">Transcription Logs</h1>
      <input
        type="text"
        placeholder="Search..."
        value={searchTerm}
        onChange={handleSearchChange}
        className="search-input"
      />
      <table className="logs-table">
        <thead>
          <tr>
            <th>File</th>
            <th>Action</th>
          </tr>
        </thead>
        <tbody>
          {currentLogs.length > 0 ? (
            currentLogs.map((log, index) => (
              <tr key={index}>
                <td>
                  <i
                    className="fas fa-file-pdf"
                    style={{ marginLeft: "8px", color: "#d9534f" }}
                  ></i>{" "}
                  Transcription {indexOfFirstLog + index + 1}
                  {/* PDF Icon */}
                </td>
                <td>
                  <a
                    href={`${log}`}
                    download
                    target="_blank"
                    rel="noopener noreferrer"
                  >
                    Download
                  </a>
                </td>
              </tr>
            ))
          ) : (
            <tr>
              <td colSpan={2}>No logs found</td>
            </tr>
          )}
        </tbody>
      </table>
      <div className="pagination">
        {Array.from(
          { length: Math.ceil(filteredLogs.length / logsPerPage) },
          (_, index) => (
            <button
              key={index}
              onClick={() => handlePageChange(index + 1)}
              className={`page-button ${
                currentPage === index + 1 ? "active" : ""
              }`}
            >
              {index + 1}
            </button>
          )
        )}
      </div>
    </div>
  );
};

export default Logs;

Summary of Updates

  2. Ensured Correct Data Handling: Added checks to ensure that logs is properly initialized and matches the expected format.
  3. Handled Edge Cases: Made sure the component gracefully handles empty states and errors.

Updated Logs.tsx with Debounce

typescript
import React, { useEffect, useState } from "react";
import { useVideoClient } from "../VideoClientContext";
import "@fortawesome/fontawesome-free/css/all.min.css"; // Import FontAwesome CSS
import logo from "../../assets/HomePage/logo.png";
import "./Logs.css";
import home from "../../assets/HomePage/home.png";
import { useNavigate } from "react-router-dom";
import debounce from 'lodash.debounce'; // Import debounce function from lodash

const Logs: React.FC = () => {
  const { user } = useVideoClient(); // Get user from context
  const [logs, setLogs] = useState<string[]>([]);
  const [filteredLogs, setFilteredLogs] = useState<string[]>([]);
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState<boolean>(true);
  const [error, setError] = useState<string | null>(null);
  const [searchTerm, setSearchTerm] = useState<string>("");
  const [currentPage, setCurrentPage] = useState<number>(1);
  const logsPerPage = 6;
  const navigate = useNavigate(); // Initialize useNavigate hook
  const server_ip = "rmvideocall.vercel.app";

  useEffect(() => {
    const fetchLogs = async () => {
      if (!user) {
        setError("User not logged in");
        setLoading(false);
        return;
      }

      try {
        const response = await fetch(
          `https://${server_ip}/api/fetchlogs?userId=${user.id}`,
          {
            method: "GET",
            headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
          }
        );
        if (!response.ok) {
          const errorText = await response.text();
          console.error(
            `Failed to fetch logs: ${response.status} - ${response.statusText}\n${errorText}`
          );
          throw new Error(
            `Failed to fetch logs: ${response.status} - ${response.statusText}\n${errorText}`
          );
        }
        const data = await response.json();
        setLogs(data);
        setFilteredLogs(data);
      } catch (err: any) {
        console.error("Error fetching logs:", err.message);
        setError(`Failed to fetch logs: ${err.message}`);
      } finally {
        setLoading(false);
      }
    };

    fetchLogs();
  }, [user]);

  const handleLogout = () => {
    console.log("Navigating to home...");
    navigate("/home");
  };

  // Debounced version of the filtering function
  const filterLogs = debounce((searchTerm: string) => {
    const results = logs.filter((log) =>
      log.toLowerCase().includes(searchTerm.toLowerCase())
    );
    setFilteredLogs(results);
    setCurrentPage(1); // Reset to first page when search term changes
  }, 300); // Adjust debounce delay as needed

  useEffect(() => {
    filterLogs(searchTerm);
  }, [searchTerm]);

  const indexOfLastLog = currentPage * logsPerPage;
  const indexOfFirstLog = indexOfLastLog - logsPerPage;
  const currentLogs = filteredLogs.slice(indexOfFirstLog, indexOfLastLog);

  const handleSearchChange = (event: React.ChangeEvent<HTMLInputElement>) => {
    setSearchTerm(event.target.value);
  };

  const handlePageChange = (pageNumber: number) => {
    setCurrentPage(pageNumber);
  };

  if (loading) return <div>Loading logs...</div>;
  if (error) return <div>Error: {error}</div>;

  return (
    <div className="logs-container">
      <nav className="navbar">
        <div className="brand-logo">
          <img src={logo} alt="Logo" />
        </div>
        <img
          src={home}
          onClick={handleLogout}
          alt="Exit"
          className="exit-icon"
        />
      </nav>
      <h1 className="title">Transcription Logs</h1>
      <input
        type="text"
        placeholder="Search..."
        value={searchTerm}
        onChange={handleSearchChange}
        className="search-input"
      />
      <table className="logs-table">
        <thead>
          <tr>
            <th>File</th>
            <th>Action</th>
          </tr>
        </thead>
        <tbody>
          {currentLogs.length > 0 ? (
            currentLogs.map((log, index) => (
              <tr key={index}>
                <td>
                  <i
                    className="fas fa-file-pdf"
                    style={{ marginLeft: "8px", color: "#d9534f" }}
                  ></i>{" "}
                  Transcription {indexOfFirstLog + index + 1}
                  {/* PDF Icon */}
                </td>
                <td>
                  <a
                    href={`${log}`}
                    download
                    target="_blank"
                    rel="noopener noreferrer"
                  >
                    Download
                  </a>
                </td>
              </tr>
            ))
          ) : (
            <tr>
              <td colSpan={2}>No logs found</td>
            </tr>
          )}
        </tbody>
      </table>
      <div className="pagination">
        {Array.from(
          { length: Math.ceil(filteredLogs.length / logsPerPage) },
          (_, index) => (
            <button
              key={index}
              onClick={() => handlePageChange(index + 1)}
              className={`page-button ${
                currentPage === index + 1 ? "active" : ""
              }`}
            >
              {index + 1}
            </button>
          )
        )}
      </div>
    </div>
  );
};

export default Logs;

Summary of Updates

  1. Debounce Implementation: Added debounce to the filterLogs function using lodash's debounce method to avoid excessive filtering operations on every keystroke.
  2. Immediate Table Update: The table will now update immediately as you type in the search bar, thanks to the filterLogs function being debounced.
